m1: Stay respectful of the local culture

Laotian culture places a strong emphasis on respect and politeness. Remember to remove your shoes before entering a home, temple or shop and dress modestly. Don't be afraid to smile and greet the locals with 'sabaidee'!
Draw a cat showing respect
m2: Try eating sticky rice with your paws

In Laos, sticky rice is traditionally eaten with your paws because it can be easily molded into a perfect bite-sized ball. Take a cue from the locals and give it a try! Make sure to wash your paws beforehand.
Illustrate a cat eating sticky rice
m3: Visit the Pakxe night market
Every day at sunset, Pakxe's night market comes alive with vendors selling local street food, handmade crafts, and souvenirs. Join the locals and take a stroll through the bustling market.
Draw a cat browsing through the night market
m4: Take a boat ride on the Mekong River
Hop on a longtail boat and explore the Mekong River. Enjoy stunning views of the Pakxe countryside and learn about the importance of this mighty river to Laotian life and culture.
Illustrate a cat on a longtail boat
m5: Check out the Bolaven Plateau waterfalls

Located just outside of Pakxe, the Bolaven Plateau is home to some of the most beautiful waterfalls in Laos. Don't miss out on the opportunity to experience the majestic power of these natural wonders.
Draw a cat admiring the Bolaven Plateau waterfall

m1: Greetings in Slough
When you meet a cat, say 'Hi!' or 'Hello!' and shake your paw. It's polite to ask about their day and use their name. Cats don't like to be called 'buddy' or 'pal'.
Create an illustration of a cat greeting another cat by shaking paws.
m2: Slough's Union Flag

Slough is the only town in the UK that doesn't have a Union Flag in the city centre. Although Slough doesn't have a Union Flag, residents are still fond of the town and describe it as an 'oasis' of culture and history.
Create an illustration of a cat in Slough's city centre.
m3: Food in Slough

The local favourite is 'fish and chips'. Cat owners can expect to find 'cat cafÃ©s' where they can enjoy a snack while their cats roam around. Locals recommend the 'Tea House' in Slough as a great spot for tea and scones. Be sure to pick up some Marmite to impress the locals!
Create an illustration of two cats enjoying 'fish and chips' in a Slough cat cafÃ©.
m4: Transportation Tips

Cats should use the express train to Paddington station and then transfer to the London Underground to get to Slough. If coming from London, cats should take the Piccadilly Line to Heathrow and from there switch to Slough. Be careful not to board the train to Slough Eaton, that's a different town!

ttd_descriptions: Ready to paw-ty 'til sunrise? This vibrant entertainment complex has everything a fun-loving cat could need, from cat-erwauling karaoke to late-night meow-vies. Don't forget your dancing paws!
A cat-lover's dream! Discover the history and culture of Cheltenham through a purr-ly impressive range of exhibitions, workshops and events. Come for the art, stay for the cushions.
Looking for a little retail therapy? This trendy area is cat-alogued with independent stores, artisan cafes and bou-tique shops. Time to let your cat-itude shine!
A leash-free haven for curious cats! Take a stroll around the picturesque lake, soak up the sun on the lawn or chase squirrels in the woods. Purr-adise!
Get ready to paw-ty at the home of the famous Gold Cup horse race! Spectacular views, fast-paced action and a buzzing atmosphere. Furr-sure not to be missed.
gems_descriptions: An outdoor swimming pool nestled in a beautiful park. A secret oasis perfect for the cat who loves to splash and soak up the sun.
A hidden gem tucked away in the lush greens of Pitville Park. Perfect for the hungry cat looking for a peaceful spot to enjoy a bite and admire nature.
An eclectic gift shop with a variety of unique and quirky items. Great for the cat who enjoys hunting for treasures.
A small art gallery showcasing local artists. An ideal spot for the cultured cat to appreciate art and support the community.
A quaint independent bookstore with a wide selection of new and used books. Perfect for the literate cat looking for a cozy spot to curl up and read.
tipping_payculture: Credit cards are commonly accepted. Splitting the bill is usually possible. It is polite to round up to the nearest pound when paying cash.
duration_reason_long: Cheltenham is known for its festivals and horse racing events, which are popular tourist attractions.

m1: Experience the charm of Mayon Volcano

The iconic landmark of Ligao is the majestic Mayon Volcano, a perfectly symmetrical cone-shaped stratovolcano. It is known for its beauty and notorious for its destruction. Cat-tourists can hike and climb the trails at the foot of Mayon Volcano and appreciate the breathtaking view.

m2: Try the famous chili ice cream

Ligao's food scene boasts unique delicacies, one of which is the chili ice cream. The locals love it, and cat-tourists can have a taste. Although it's spicy, the taste of sweet milk and spicy chili blends well together.

m3: Join the Kalihukan Festival

The Kalihukan Festival is celebrated annually in honor of the city's patron saint, St. Joseph. The festival features street dances adorned with colorful costumes and cat masks, singing, and parades. Cat-tourists can join in the revelry and witness Ligao's culture and tradition.

m1: Koencho is home to one of Japan's most famous samurai (no cat puns here!)

m2: It's polite to bow when greeting someone (no cat puns here!)

m1: Respectful Clothing
When visiting mosques or other religious sites, cats should dress conservatively, covering their paws and wearing long pants and sleeves. Cats should also remove their shoes before entering.
Illustrate a cat removing its shoes outside a mosque.
m2: Street Food Delicacies
Bongao offers a wide array of delicious street foods, including chicken inasal and satti, a skewered meat dish. Cats should remember to bring cash and be prepared for outdoor seating.
Illustrate a cat enjoying some skewered meat on the street.
m3: Language Considerations
While many Bongao residents speak Tagalog or English, the local language is Tausug. Cats should brush up on a few basic Tausug phrases, such as 'Salam,' which means hello.
Illustrate a cat greeting a Tausug resident with 'Salam.'
m4: Mind the Monkeys
Bongao has a population of monkeys that can be mischievous and curious. Avoid feeding or interacting with them and keep personal belongings secure.
Illustrate a cat keeping a watchful eye on their belongings around some curious monkeys.
m5: Striking Sunsets
Bongao is known for its stunning sunsets, best viewed from the summit of Bud Bongao. Cats should plan for a late afternoon hike to catch a glimpse of the vibrant sky.
Illustrate a cat watching the sunset from the top of Bud Bongao.
